Description:
The Group of 77 (G-77) was established on 15 June 1964 by seventy-seven developing countries signatories of the “Joint Declaration of the Seventy-Seven Developing Countries” issued at the end of the first session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development UNCTAD in Geneva.
The Group of 77 is the largest intergovernmental organization of developing countries in the United Nations, which provides the means for the countries of the South to articulate and promote their collective economic interests and enhance their joint negotiating capacity on all major international economic issues within the United Nations system, and promote South-South cooperation for development.
Member states: Afghanistan, Algeria, Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Benin, Bhutan, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Bosnia and Herzegovina, Botswana, Brazil, Brunei Darussalam, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cambodia, Cameroon, Cabo Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Chile, China, Colombia, Comoros, Congo, Costa Rica, Côte d'Ivoire, Cuba, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Fiji, Gabon, Gambia, Ghana, Grenada, Guatemala, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, India, Indonesia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Iraq, Jamaica, Jordan, Kenya, Kiribati, Kuwait, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Lebanon, Lesotho, Liberia, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Malaysia, Maldives, Mali, Marshall Islands, Mauritania, Mauritius, Micronesia (Federated States of), Mongolia, Morocco, Mozambique, Myanmar, Namibia, Nauru, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Panama, Papua New Guinea, Paraguay, Peru, Philippines, Qatar, Rwanda, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Samoa, Sao Tome and Principe, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Somalia, South Africa, South Sudan, Sri Lanka, State of Palestine, Sudan, Suriname, Swaziland, Syrian Arab Republic, Tajikistan, Thailand, Timor-Leste, Togo, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Turkmenistan, Uganda, United Arab Emirates, United Republic of Tanzania, Uruguay, Vanuatu, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of), Viet Nam, Yemen, Zambia, Zimbabwe

Description: The Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS) is an intergovernmental organization of low-lying coastal and small island countries. Established in 1990, the main purpose of the alliance is to consolidate the voices of Small Island Developing States (SIDS) to address global warming. AOSIS has been very active from its inception, putting forward the first draft text in the Kyoto Protocol negotiations as early as 1994.
Member states: Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Cape Verde, Comoros, Cook Islands, Cuba, Dominica. Dominican Republic, Fiji. Federated States of Micronesia, Grenada, Guinea-Bissau, Guyana, Haiti, Jamaica, Kiribati, Maldives, Marshall Islands, Mauritius, Nauru, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Singapore, Seychelles, Sao Tome and Principe, Solomon Islands, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Suriname, Timor-Leste, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Tuvalu, Vanuatu

Description: The 50 countries defined as Least Developed Countries (LDC) by the UN regularly work together in the wider UN system. They have become increasingly active in the climate change process, often working together to defend their particular interests, for example with regard to vulnerability and adaptation to climate change.
Member states: Angola, Bangladesh, Benin, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cambodia, Central African Republic, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Myanmar, Nepal, Niger, Rwanda, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Solomon Islands, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Vanuatu, Yemen, Zambia

Description: The 28 members of the European Union (EU) meet in private to agree on common negotiating positions. The country that holds the EU Presidency - a position that rotates every six months - then speaks for the European Union and its 28 member states. As a regional economic integration organization, the European Union itself can be, and is, a Party to the Convention. However, it does not have a separate vote from its members.
Member states: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, European Union (formerly EC), Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom

Description: Formed during the early days of UNFCC convention, the Umbrella Group mainly consists of the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Russia, whose stance regarding climate change is less enthusiastic than most of the developed signatories to the Kyoto Protocol.
Member states: Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, Kazakhstan, Norway, the Russian Federation, Ukraine and the US

Description: The Environmental Integrity Group (EIG), formed in 2000, is an unlikely alliance between Mexico, Liechtenstein, Monaco, the Republic of Korea and Switzerland. The EIG is the only party group that crosses frontiers between the very fragmented interests of developed and developing countries.
Member states: Mexico, Switzerland, South Korea

Expressions: Independent association of Latin America and the Caribbean|AILAC
Item: Independent association of Latin America and the Caribbean
Description: The Independent Association of Latin America and the Caribbean (AILAC) is a grouping of countries from Latin America and the Caribbean that cooperate on certain issues as a block in international climate negotiations. The group was created in 2012, during the 18th Conference of the Parties by Colombia, Costa Rica, Chile, Peru, Guatemala and Panama and supported by the Dominican Republic, breaking from the Group of 77 on some issues notably the level of commitments for developing countries. The group presents itself as a "third way" in the North–South, rich–poor divide in climate change negotiations.
Member states: Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay, Perou

Description: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) was established September 1960. OPEC's mandate is to coordinate and unify the petroleum policies of its members in the context of the shifting role of fossil fuels in the global economy today.
Member states: Islamic Republic of Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela Qatar, Indonesia, Libya , the United Arab Emirates, Algeria, Nigeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Angola

Expressions: Central Asia, Caucasus, Albania and Moldova|CACAM
Item: Central Asia, Caucasus, Albania and Moldova
Description: Central Asia, Caucasus, Albania and Moldova (CACAM) is a negotiation group formed at the COP-6 in 2000. The raison d’être of the group is to clarify the status of its members in the climate change regime. Typically, the convention recognizes Annex 1 Parties with economies in transition and non-Annex 1 Parties that are developing countries, but not non-Annex 1 Parties with economies in transition, which what CACAM countries perceive themselves to be.
Member states: Unknown  - Caucasus, Albania, Moldova

Description: The Arab league or League of Arab States is a regional organization of Arab countries in and around North Africa, the Horn of Africa and Arabia. It was formed in 1945 in Cairo. (further research on position)
Member states: Egypt, Iraq, Jordan (originally Transjordan, Jordan, as of 1950), Yemen, Algeria, Bahrain, Comoros, Djibouti, Kuwait, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Somalia, Southern Yemen, Sudan, Tunisia, The United Arab Emirates

Description: The Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie (OIF) is an institution whose members (states or participating governments) share French language and common values. It focuses specifically on the development and diffusion of the technical means to reduce greenhouse gas increase.
Member states: Albanie, Belgique, Bénin, Bulgarie, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cambodge, Cameroun, Canada, Canada-Nouveau-Brunswick, Canada-Québec, Cap-Vert, Centrafrique, Communauté française de Belgique, Comores, Congo, République Démocratique du Congo, Côte d'Ivoire, Djibouti, Dominique, Egypte, France, Gabon, Guinée, Guinée-Bissau, Guinée Equatoriale, Haïti, Laos, Liban, Lituanie, Luxembourg, Macédoine, Madagascar, Mali, Maroc, Maurice, Mauritanie, Moldavie, Monaco, Niger, Pologne, République Tchèque, Roumanie, Rwanda, Sainte-Lucie, Sao Tomé et Principe, Sénégal, Seychelles, Slovénie, Suisse, Tchad, Togo, Tunisie, Vanuatu, Vietnam

Expressions: Bolivarian Alliance For The Peoples Of Our America|ALBA
Item: Bolivarian Alliance For The Peoples Of Our America
Description: Founded initially by Cuba and Venezuela in 2004, the Bolivarian Alliance for the Peoples of Our America (ALBA) is associated with socialist and social democratic governments wishing to consolidate regional economic integration based on a vision of social welfare, bartering and mutual economic aid. ALBA countries have taken positions strongly against carbon markets.
Member states: Cuba, Venezuela, Bolivia, Nicaragua, Dominican Republic, Antigua-and-Barbuda, Ecuador, Saint-Vincent-and-Grenadines, Sainte-Lucie, Saint-Christophe-and-Niévès, Grenada.

Description: The Central American Integration System (SICA) is the economic and political organization of Central American states since 1993. It focuses on protecting and valorizing the environmental heritage of its member states with a more optimal, coordinated, use of legislative tools.
Member states: Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama, Dominican Republic

Expressions: Like Minded Group of Developing Countries|LMDC
Item: Like Minded Group of Developing Countries
Description: The Like Minded Group of Developing Countries (LMDC) is a group of developing countries that organize themselves as a negotiating block in international organizations such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, where they represent more than 50% of the world's population. They have expressed concern about the eligibility criteria for climate finance.
Member states: Algeria, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bhutan, China, Egypt, Cuba, India, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka. Soudan, Syria, Vietnam, Zimbabwe

Description: The Africa Group of Negotiators (AGN) was formed in 2013 for the 19th Conference of Parties. It is an alliance that consists of climate change negotiators from every African country. Africa, which is responsible for less than three per cent of total global emissions, bears the brunt of climate change; they are calling for a post Kyoto climate change agreement that better reflects that fact.
Member states: Algeria, Angola, Benin, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Cape Verde Central Africa Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote D’Ivoire, DR Congo, Djibouti, Egypt, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Gabon, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Libyan AJ, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mauritius, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Sudan, Swaziland, Togo, Tunisia, Uganda, UR of Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe

Description: The Latin American and Caribbean Group (GRULAC) is one of the five unofficial Regional Groups in the United Nations that act as voting blocs and negotiation forums. Coming unto the COP 21 in Paris, the group has pushed for better South-South cooperation and a more nuanced approach to poverty metrics that go beyond aggregate figures such as Gross National Product (GDP).
Member states: Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina Bahamas Barbados Belize Bolivia Brazil Chile Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Grenada Guatemala Guyana Haiti Honduras Jamaica Mexico Nicaragua Panama Paraguay Peru, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Uruguay, Venezuela

Description: The Valdivia group was formed in 1995 in order to increase cooperation between its members, located south of the Capricorn tropic. They focus on producing scientific cooperation between southern hemisphere scientists in order to advance southern interests.
Member states: Argentina, Australia, Chile, New Zealand, South Africa and Uruguay

Description: The Asian-Pacific group is one of the five unofficial Regional Groups in the United Nations that act as voting blocs and negotiation forums.
Member states: Afghanistan, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, China, Cyprus, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Iraq, Japan, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Lebanon, Malaysia, Maldives, Marshall Islands, Micronesia (Federated States of), Mongolia, Myanmar, Nauru,   Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Qatar, Republic of Korea, Samoa, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Solomon Islands, Sri Lanka, Syrian Arab Republic, Tajikistan, Thailand, Timor-Leste, Tonga, Turkmenistan, Tuvalu, United Arab Emirates, Uzbekistan, Vanuatu, Viet Nam, Yemen

Description: The Coalition for Rainforest Nations (CfRN) was formed in 2005. Established by forested tropical countries in an attempt to collaboratively reconcile forest stewardship with economic development, the Rainforest Coalition aims to bring together both developing and industrialized nations for the purpose of creating community-driven, environmentally sustainable economic growth.
Member states: Cameroon, Central African Republic, Democratic Republic of Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Madagascar, Nigeria, Republic of Congo, Sierra Leone, Uganda, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Bangladesh, Malaysia, Pakistan, Republic of Indonesia, Thailand, Viet Nam, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, Guyana, Paraguay, Suriname, Uruguay.

Description: The Eastern European Group (EEG), also known as Countries with Economies in Transition (CEIT), is one of the five unofficial Regional Groups in the United Nations that act as voting blocs and negotiation forums.
Member states: Albania Armenia Azerbaijan Belarus Bosnia Herzegovina Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia Georgia Hungary Latvia Lithuania Montenegro Poland, Republic of Moldova, Romania, Russian Federation, Serbia Slovakia Slovenia, The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Ukraine

Description: The Western European and Others Group (WEOG) is one of five unofficial Regional Groups in the United Nations that act as voting blocs and negotiation forums
Member states: Andorra Australia  Austria Belgium Canada Denmark Finland  France Germany Greece Iceland Ireland Israel Italy Lichtenstein Luxembourg Malta Monaco Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway , Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden Switzerland Turkey USA*, UK

Expressions: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD
Item: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Description: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is an international economic organisation of 34 countries, founded in 1961 to stimulate economic progress and world trade. They focus on independent scientific research in order to guide governmental climate change policy.
Member states: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chile, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Luxembourg, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, United Kingdom, United States, European Union.

Expressions: Brazil, South Africa, India and China|Brazil South Africa India and China|BASIC
Item: Brazil, South Africa, India and China
Description: The BASIC countries are a bloc of four large newly industrialized countries – Brazil, South Africa, India and China – formed by an agreement on 28 November 2009. The four committed to act jointly at the Copenhagen climate summit.
Member states: Brazil, South Africa, India, China

Description: With the Kyoto Protocol ending in 2012, countries agreed in Doha in 2012 to a "second commitment period" from 2013 to 2020. In the continuation of the Kyoto Protocol, Parties committed to reduce GHG emissions by at least 18 percent below 1990 levels.

Following the establishement of the UNFCCC in 1992, which stressed Parties' willingness to cooperate on the issue of climate change, Parties negotiated a protocol that would set concrete reduction targets, agreed in Kyoto in 1997. Within this protocol Annex I countries (developed countries) agreed to an average of five percent against 1990 levels, while non Annex-I countries (developing countries) do not have any commitment.

Within the Kyoto Protocol, Parties have been discussing ways to assist countries in complying with their emission reduction targets and possible consequences for not meeting their commitments. This issue is dealt with by the Compliance Committee, which is made of a facilitative branch and enforcement branch.

Under the Kyoto Protocol, countries must meet their targets primarily through national measures. However, the protocol also offers them additional means to meet their targets by way of three market-based mechanisms: the International Emissions Trading, the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) and the Joint implementation (JI).

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has played a significant role in guiding the UNFCCC with effectively dealing with climate change, by publishing e.g Assessment and Special reports. The structure of the IPCC and the way it produces expertise is essential in enhancing the translation and circulation of scientific knowledge.

According to scientific expertise, climate change will have significant impacts on natural and human ecosystems, that have already started to be felt in different parts of the world, and especially in developing countries. Being the most vulnerable, these countries are requesting developed countries to assist them in meeting the cost of adaptation.

According to scientific expertise, climate change will cause significant damage to e.g human health, water ressources. Sea level rise and weather extremes e.g floods and droughts will be expected more frequently. These represent climate risks.

Researches have demonstrated that climate change is primiraly due to growing anthropogenic emissions of CO2, which interfere with the global climate system and cause temperature rise. This requires a coordinated system of earth observation as well as cooperation with other conventions (biodiversity, desertification).

The ratification of the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 has raised technical and political questions on how to implement it. This has been dealt with within the CMP (Meeting of the Parties) and the SBI (Subsidiary Body for Implementation)

Expressions: Financial Mechanism and Funds (1)|Financial Mechanism and Funds
Description: Countries having different capacities in responding to climate change, especially developing countries, the UNFCCC established a financial mechanism to help them cope with the consequences of climate change. The Convention entrusted the GEF (Global Environment Facility) and later the Green Climate Fund (GCF).

In addition to providing financial resources to help developing countries cope with climate change, developed countries are also required to support technology transfer to assist them in completing emission inventories and heading towards a low carbon economy.

The ratification of the UNFCCC has trigerred the establishement of numerous bodies that contribute to its implementation: these are e.g subsidary bodies (SBI and SBSTA), a Secretariat, financial mechanism. The UNFCCC also gather a variety of actors: delegations, observer organizations, the United Nations. They meet in high-level segments, ministerial segments, which function following given rules of procedures.

REDD (Reducing emissions from deforestation in developing countries), or REDD plus (which includes forest degradation and other forest management options) is a mechanism that essentially aims at financially rewarding developing countries for their efforts to reduce emissions and enhance removals of greenhouse gases through a variety of forest management options.

This issue concerns adverse impacts on developing countries "both of climate change and of response measures aimed at mitigating climate change", that is e.g., impacts on highly vulnerable countries such as small island countries, but also economic impacts on countries whose economies are highly dependent on fossil fuel.

All Parties to the UNFCCC are required to provide different communications (national reports) on their efforts to implement the UNFCCCbased on their status as Annex I (developed countries) and non-Annex I Parties (developing countries). These include reports on e.g annual inventories of emissions and removals of GHGs or measures to mitigate and to facilitate adequate adaptation to climate change.

Mitigation is one of two major measures (with adaptation) to tackle climate change. It refers to efforts and measures to reduce GHG emissions and enhance sinks and reservoirs. Mitigation has been mainly dealt with within the Kyoto Protocol (1997), which set emission reduction atrget to Annex I countries (developed countries), whereas non-Annex I (developing countries) have no reduction commitment in accordance with the principle of "common but differentiated responsibilities".

Adaptation is one of the two major measures (with mitigation) to tackle climate change. While mitigation was prioritized in the first decade of the UNFCCC, adaptation raised as an equally relevant issue in the 2000s following increased acknowledgement that mitigation actions would not suffice and that some impacts would be still be felt. Adaptation is mainly discussed through financial support and technology transfer for the most vulnerable countries.

The end of the Kyoto Protocol in 2012 has triggered legal questions on further commitments by all Parties (Annex I and non-Annex I) from 2013-2020 (second commitment period to the Kyoto Protocol) and 2020 (new agreement): e.g the legal status of the different draft agreements, the legal force of the new agreement.

The end of the Kyoto Protocol in 2012 has launched a new round of negotiations on its successor. It was expended in 2012 for another 7 years (2013 - 2020) before leading to a new agreement from 2020, which would set emission reduction targets for both developed and developing countries (Annex I and non-Annex I countries). While the Kyoto Protocol is viewed as a top-down agreement (where a common global goal for reducing emissions was agreed and then divided between countries), the new agreement should rather follow a ‘bottom-up’ approach with countries making their own, non-binding, voluntary targets to reduce carbon emissions
